children.name: sb with special powers to predict
fortune teller
children.definition: /ˈfɔːʳtʃən ˌteləʳ/  someone who tells people what will happen to them in the future and is paid for doing this:
examples: thầy bói
▪ I went to see a fortune teller, and she told me that I would meet the man of my dreams and have three children.

children.name: clairvoyant
children.definition: /kleəʳˈvɔɪənt/  someone who has the ability to know what will happen in the future:nhà ngoại cảm
examples: ▪ A clairvoyant predicted that something terrible would happen to the President.
clairvoyance[countable noun] the ability to know what will happen in the future:
khả năngngoại cảm
▪ Local legends told of a family in which the women were all cursed with clairvoyance.

children.name: psychic
children.definition: /ˈsaɪkɪk/  spoken someone who is psychic is able to know what will happen in the future - used especially when saying that you cannot know what will happen, or when you are surprised that someone knew that something would happen:bà đồng, ông đồng
examples: ▪ How was I supposed to know she’d react like that? I’m not psychic!
▪ How did you know I’d be here? You must be psychic!

children.name: to say what will happen in the future
predict
children.definition: to say what you think will happen in the future:dự đoán
examples: Most of the papers are predicting an easy victory for the Dallas Cowboys.
a major earthquake that no-one had predicted
Sales were five percent lower than predicted.
AsLizhad predicted, the rumours were soon forgotten.
predict (that)
Newspapers predicted that Davis would be re-elected.
predict whether/what/how etc
It is difficult to predict what the long-term effects of the accident will be.
be predicted to do sth
Unemployment is predicted to increase to 700,000 by the end of the year.

children.name: forecast
children.definition: to publicly say what will happen in the future with the weather or the economic or political situation, especially when you have special or technical knowledge:dự báo
examples: ▪ Property analysts forecast a fall in house prices.
forecast rain/fine weather/snow etc
▪ Rain is forecast for all parts of southern England tomorrow.
forecast (that)
▪ Hardly anyone had forecast that the drought would last so long.

children.name: prophesy
children.definition: to say that sth will happen, especially because you have religious or magical powers:tiên đoán
examples: ▪ It is claimed that Ebba prophesied her own death from the plague.
prophesy that
▪ Jesus prophesied that one of his disciples would betray him.
prophesy about
▪ Her ability to prophesy about the future made many people think she was a witch.

children.name: foretell
children.definition: to say what will happen in the future, especially by using magical powers - used in literature and stories:tiên tri, tiên đoán
examples: Nostradamus is said to have foretold the rise of Hitler.
Everything happened as Merlin foretold.
the birth of Christ, foretold by prophets

children.name: second-guess
children.definition: to try to predict what an opponent will do in order to gain an advantage over them:đoán
examples: I just couldn’t get the ball past him; he second-guessed me every time.
Second-guessing the bank’s next move in the takeover bid proved very difficult.

children.name: project
children.definition: to say what the amount, size, cost etc of sth is likely to be in the future, using the information you have now : dự tính
examples: The company projected an annual growth rate of 3%.
projected sales figures
The world’s population is projected to rise by 45%.
be projected to do something
Total expenditure is projected to rise by 25%.

children.name: to think you know sth is going to happen in the future
foresee
children.definition: to know that sth is going to happen before it actually happens:biết trước, thấy trước
examples: I’ve put your name on the list and I don’t foresee any problems.
The disaster could not have been foreseen.
No one foresaw the Great Depression of the thirties.
Businesses are alarmed at the costs they foresee in complying with the new rules.
foresee that
Few analysts foresaw that oil prices would rise so steeply.
Ten years ago she could not have foreseen that her marriage would end in divorce.
foresee what/how etc
No one foresaw what he was planning.

children.name: envisage
children.definition: /envision slightly formal to have a clear idea of sth that will happen in the future, especially important changes in a situation:nhìn trước, dự tính
examples: I cannot envisage what the circumstances will be in twenty years’ time.
Most of those who voted for independence did not envision war as the eventual outcome.
We do not envisage a general election for at least another two years.
The scheme cost a lot more than we had originally envisaged.
envisage that
It's envisagedthatthe building will start at the end of this year.
envisage doing sth
I don’t envisage working with him again.
When do you envisage finishingthe project?
envisage how/ what/ etc
It's hard to envisagehowit might happen.

children.name: see sth coming
children.definition: to know or think you know what is going to happen because there are signs that it will: thấy được
examples: Jason saw the stock market crash coming and sold most of his shares.
Then one day she just walked out -- I suppose I should have seen it coming really.

children.name: feel sth in your bones
children.definition: informal to think that sth is going to happen, especially sth bad, not for any clear or specific reason, but just because you have a feeling that it will: có linh cảm
examples: The trip’s going to be a disaster - I can feel it in my bones.

children.name: have a premonition
children.definition: to have a strange or unexplainable feeling that sth is going to happen, especially sth unpleasant: có linh cảm, thấy điềm
examples: have a premonition (that)
▪ When Paola failed to phone, John had a horrible premonition that she was in danger.
have a premonition of
▪ She shivered suddenly, and I wondered whether she had had a premonition of her own death.

children.name: see into the future U
children.definition: see into the future sb who can see into the future has the ability to know what will happen before it happens: biết trước tương lai
examples: ▪ If I could only see into the future and know how this would all end.
▪ Nobody can see into the future, and all stock exchange investment is a gamble.

children.name: sth that sb predicts will happen
prediction
children.definition: a statement about what you think is going to happen, or the act of making this statement :dự đoán
examples: Despite their confident predictions, sales of the new car have not been very good.
prediction of
predictions of a Republican victory
make a predictionIt is far too early to make predictions about the outcome of the inquiry.
The data can be used tomakeuseful economicpredictions.
confirm a prediction(= show that it was right )They are now planning further tests to confirm their predictions.
accurate/correctJane's prediction proved to be accurate.
a confident prediction(= one that you think is probably right )The situation is so uncertain that it is hard to make a confident prediction.
a dire/gloomy prediction(= saying that something bad will happen )There have been some gloomy predictions about the economy recently.

children.name: forecast
children.definition: a description of what is likely to happen in the future, based on the information that you have now, especially about the weather, economic or political situation: dự báo
examples: Theweather forecastis good for tomorrow.
a weather forecastThe weather forecast for the weekend is fine and dry.
a shipping forecast(= a forecast about weather conditions at sea )According to the shipping forecast, strong winds can be expected later today.
a sales forecastThe gloomy sales forecast sparked rumours that the company would be making job cuts.
a profit forecastThe company has cut its profit forecast by £18m to £570m.
a growth forecast(= one relating to an increase in the value of goods or services produced and sold )The official growth forecasts for the economy are promising.
an economic forecastThe Bank of England revised its economic forecast in the wake of the figures.
a detailed forecastA detailed forecast of the industry’s prospects has just been published.
optimistic(= expecting good things to happen )In his speech, the President gave an optimistic forecast for the economy.
pessimistic/gloomy(= expecting bad things to happen )Scientists have produced a gloomy forecast on the effects of global warming.
make a forecastIt is too early to make a forecast on what will happen.
give a forecastEconomists gave an upbeat forecast for the world economy.
provide a forecastAnalysts usually provide growth forecasts for no more than two years ahead.
revise a forecast(= change it because of new information )The company has revised its sales forecast.

children.name: prophecy
children.definition: 1 a statement that something will happen in the future, especially one made by someone with religious or magic powers →prophet: lời tiên tri
examples: prophecy (that)
Theprophecythat David would become King wasfulfilled.
Lij Yasu was never crowned, possibly because he believed a prophecy that if he became king he would die.
Amazingly, the manager’s prophecy that the team would get into the first division seems to be coming true.
prophecy of
the prophecy of Isaiah
The old woman’s prophecies of disaster were soon fulfilled.
2[U] the power or act of making statements about what will happen in the future : tiên tri
She had the gift of prophecy.

children.name: prognosis
children.definition: formala judgment about the future, based on information or experience : dự đoán
examples: By the early 1990s the prognosis for Communism wasn’t at all good.
prognosis of
a hopeful prognosis of the country’s future development

children.name: projection
children.definition: a statement or calculation about what sth will be in the future or was in the past, based on information available now : dự tính
examples: projection of
projections of declining natural gas production
projection for
population projections for the next 25 years
He declined tomake projectionsabout fourth quarter earnings.
Early projections show a three point lead for the Socialists.

children.name: predicted U
children.definition: predicted showing what sb thinks will happen in the future:được dự đoán
examples: More than a century after Marx, the predicted dissolution of capitalism has still not taken place.
There were several arrests for disorderly behaviour, but for the most part the much-predicted violence did not materialize.

children.name: projected
children.definition: projected figures/sales/profits/resultsthe profits, sales etc that a business expects to achieve considering past and present performance:dự tính
examples: Next year’s projected sales are 5% higher than this year’s.
The company’s losses look likely to wipe out the projected profits on the ECR90 project.

children.name: predictable
children.definition: if sb/sth is predictable, you know what will happen or what they will do – sometimes used to show disapproval : có thể dự đoán
examples: The drug is usually effective but unfortunately the side effects are not always predictable.
There are few predictable elements to this conflict -- the only certainty is that the situation will worsen before it gets better.
Comets appear at predictable times.
The snow had a predictable effect on traffic.
an entertaining but predictable film
Logan’s reaction was predictable.
it is predictable that
In the current economic climate it is fairly predictable that unemployment will continue to rise.
predictablyadverb[ sentence adverb ] :
Predictably, no one was home when I called.
predictability/ prɪˌdɪktəˈbɪləti, prɪˌdɪktəˈbɪlɪti /noun[ uncountable ]

children.name: foreseeable
children.definition: able to be predicted within a particular period of time in the future: dự đoán được, có thể thấy được
examples: Due to rising costs and delays in the delivery of equipment, losses are already foreseeable on the new tunnel project.
in/for the foreseeable future
There will not be any redundancies in the foreseeable future.
He asked me if there was any point in the foreseeable future when I'd like to have children.
I'll certainly carry on living here for the foreseeable future.
foreseeable circumstances
Your insurance policy should take into account all foreseeable circumstances.

children.name: can’t say
children.definition: /tell  informal to be unable to say or predict what will happen:không thể nói trước
examples: can’t say/tell how/what/whether
▪ The doctors can’t say whether he will recover at this stage.
▪ I don’t know if we’ll stay together or not. I can’t tell how I’ll be feeling in a month’s time.

children.name: unpredictable
children.definition: sth that is unpredictable is impossible to predict because the situation changes a lot and has no regular pattern:không thể dự đoán
examples: ▪ Britain is well known for its unpredictable weather.
▪ Mayoral elections are usually unpredictable, highly dependent on the particular appeal of personalities and the ability to form coalitions.
highly unpredictable
▪ The situation in the region’s poorest country remains volatile and highly unpredictable.

children.name: unforeseeable
children.definition: a situation or event, especially a bad one, that is unforeseeable could not have been predicted because it is the result of unusually bad luck:không đoán trước được
examples: ▪ What happened the following weekend was as unforeseeable as a plane falling on your house.
▪ The circumstances which combined to cause this accident were unforeseeable.

children.name: it remains to be seen
children.definition: use this to show that you are unable or unwilling to say what will happen, and so people have to wait and see:chưa biết được
examples: ▪ ‘What is your next film going to be about?’ ‘Well, that remains to be seen.’
▪ What remains to be seen now is whether it is too late to save the rainforests.
it remains to be seen how/when/if etc
▪ It remains to be seen how many senior citizens will actually benefit from this new plan.

children.name: bet
children.definition: verbbetting,bet,bet
examples: [ T ]informalIf you say you bet (someone) that something is true or will happen, you mean you are certain that it is true or will happen
[ + ( that ) ]I bet you(that)she's missed the bus. I bet(that)he won't come.

children.name: omen
children.definition: sth that happens which you think is a sign that something good or bad is going to happen in the future: điềm báo
examples: Do you think the rain is some kind of omen?
The car won’t start. Do you think it’s an omen?
a good/bad/ill omen
The mist seemed like a bad omen and Sara’s heart sank a little.
George thought the car breaking down on the way to his wedding was a bad omen.
‘Maybe this is a good omen,’ said Jill, seeing a blue sky for the first time in weeks.
omen of
He will regard your presence as an omen of good fortune.
omen for
It’s a good omen for the future.

children.name: ominous
children.definition: making you think that sth bad has happened or is likely to happen soon:
examples: ▪ Another wave crashed onto the deck and the mast made an ominous creaking sound.
▪ Katy answered the phone. There was an ominous silence.
sth sounds ominous
▪ My manager asked for an appointment at nine o'clock on a Monday morning: it sounded ominous.
ominously[adverb]
▪ When the army moved into the city, the streets were ominously silent.

children.name: prognosis
children.definition: formal the likely result of a process such as an illness that has already started:dự đoán, tiên lượng bệnh
examples: Well, doctor, what’s the prognosis?
good/poor prognosis
Doctors said Blake’s long-term prognosis is good.
